The safety of fluoride in drinking water is a topic that deserves careful consideration, and the evidence increasingly suggests that even the recommended levels—typically between 0.7 to 1.2 milligrams per liter—can pose health risks, especially when consumed over a lifetime.

One of the most well-documented concerns is dental fluorosis, which is a visible change in the appearance of tooth enamel. While mild forms may only show as faint white spots, more severe cases can lead to staining and pitting, particularly in children whose teeth are still developing. Fluoride also accumulates in the body over time. Because it is not efficiently excreted, it can build up in bones and soft tissues.
